unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Not as Much Tattoo Ink? Find the $p$-Value
question_text:
Travis recently heard a report claiming that $35\%$ of young adults have at least one tattoo. He thinks that the actual percentage is lower for students at his university. To investigate, he randomly selects $60\text{ students}$ from his university and finds that $17$ of them have at least one tattoo.
Assuming that all conditions have been satisfied, what is the $p$-value for the appropriate significance test?
solution:
We should conduct a one-sample $z$-test for proportions with the following hypotheses:

$H_0: p = 0.35$
$H_a: p < 0.35$

...where $p$ is the proportion of students at this university who have at least one tattoo.

Since we are assuming our conditions to be satisfied, we proceed to calculating the $p$-value. We begin by calculating the $z$-score related to our observation.

The formula is:

$$z = \dfrac { \hat { p } - p }{ \sqrt { \dfrac { \left( p \right) \left( 1-p \right) }{ n } } }$$

Filling in the formula, we find:

$$z = \dfrac { \dfrac { 17 }{ 60 } - 0.35 }{ \sqrt { \dfrac { \left( 0.35 \right) \left( 1-0.35 \right) }{ 60 } } } = -1.083$$
